config.text:
Environmental Racism

Environmental Impacts of Industry on First Nations Reserves in Ontario
config.placeholder: Double click to edit text

config.text: Mercury Poisoning
config.placeholder: Double click to edit text

config.text:
Between 1962 and 1970, the Dryden Chemical Plant in Dryden, Ontario, dumped approximately 10 tonnes of mercury upstream from Grassy Narrows.


The government knew for decades, and did nothing, not even warning the community.

config.text: Health Impacts
config.placeholder: Double click to edit text

config.text:
The mercury poisoning of Grassy Narrows residents created lasting health problems across generations.


People reported losing their vision, hearing, experiencing shakes and seizures, and loss of sensation, among other symptoms. Some people lost their lives.


90% of Grassy Narrows residents show symptoms of mercury poisoning.

Justice for Grassy Narrows
config.placeholder: Double click to edit text

config.text:
The image at left depicts the River Run 2016, led by the youth of Grassy Narrows. Grassy Narrows have demanded justice and compensation for the governments negligence and inaction for decades. 

Scientists say the water of the Wabigoon River system near Grassy Narrows can be cleaned, and the fish can be made safe to eat. 

While some compensation has been offered to the people of Grassy Narrows, residents say that they now fear further mercury poisoning, as the Ford government has removed Environmental Protection Assessments for clear-cut logging.

config.text:
What is Environmental Racism


Environmental racism is " a form of systemic racism whereby communities of colour are disproportionately burdened with health hazards through policies and practices that force them to live in proximity to sources of toxic waste such as sewage works, mines, landfills, power stations, major roads and emitters of airborne particulate matter".



What are Reserves?


Canada is an apartheid state, where the original people of the land remain segregated to Prisoner-of-War camps, called reserves. Until 1951, Indigenous peoples were not allowed to leave reserves except with express permission from an Indian Agent. The purpose of these reserves was to prevent Indigenous peoples from accessing their traditional territories and thus interfering with colonization. Reserves were central to other tactics of genocide, such as residential schools and starvation policies.

What are reserves like now?

Boil Water Advisories


Why do Indigenous communities living in Ontario continue to face barriers to accessing clean, fresh water on their own territories? As of February, 2021, there are 85 drinking water advisories (DWA's) on Indigenous reserves across Canada - 57 of them long-term.


There are 43 active DWA's reserves in Ontario.


There are many reasons given for these boil water advisories: pollution, remoteness, and infrastructure.



This project will aim to examine these excuses in the context of industrial impacts on reserves.
Pollution from Pipelines
Diamond Mine History
config.placeholder: Double click to edit text

config.text: The Victor Diamond Mines, located in Northern Ontario was in operation from 2006-2019. Operating equipment at the mines end of life was set to be left on site in a landfill. Concerns from the local Attawapiskat First Nations community have arose due to the landfill being upstream and the communities already poor water quality.
Mercury Poisoning
config.placeholder: Double click to edit text

config.text:
Between 1962 and 1970, the Dryden Chemical Plant in Dryden, Ontario, dumped approximately 10 tonnes of mercury upstream from Grassy Narrows.


The government knew for decades, and did nothing, not even warning the community.
Mercury Poisoning
config.placeholder: Double click to edit text

config.text:
Between 1962 and 1970, the Dryden Chemical Plant in Dryden, Ontario, dumped approximately 10 tonnes of mercury upstream from Grassy Narrows.


The government knew for decades, and did nothing, not even warning the community.

The Attawapiskat First Nations community has never had a clean source of drinking water. Their fears arise from the level of toxins in the water. The levels are so high that residents have been asked to refrain from taking long showers or washing their food let alone drinking it.
The Water

The Issue


In the past the Attawapiskat community had been promised a system for managing their sewage and creating potable water. The system was project to cost $20.6 million. The Victor Diamond mine had annual profits of $211 million and was equipped with large industrial equipment despite the remoteness of the site. Given this it should be a non-issue for Attawapiskat to be aided in building their water infrastructure especially if the landfill is approved.

Attawapiskat First Nations:

The Water Crisis
Ontario Mineable Resources

All pipelines spill, often near reserves, because that's where the pipelines pass with no consent. Pipelines present a risk to drinking water, and spills from Alberta's diluted bitumen sink instead of floating, making cleanup impossible. Common compounds released during pipeline spills include polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH's), which can be carcinogenic, cause development impacts, and damage DNA.

The railroads in Ontario are a relic of colonization - they were used to send state troops to keep Indigenous peoples confined to reserves. Sir John A. MacDonald used genocidal starvation policies to remove Indigenous peoples from the land on which the Canadian railway was built. The railway was then used to send white colonizers West, in order to settle more land. A procession of metal caskets carrying stolen goods: clickety clack clickety clack, cha-ching. -Jennifer Wickham (I'm a Real Skin)

The land is very rich. There is no reason that the continued impoverishment of Indigenous nations should be tolerated. Mining activities are a source of heavy metals and other compounds leaching into the water, ground and air.

bookmarks.name: Reserves
bookmarks.title: Bookmark-1
bookmarks.description: This bookmark zooms to show the size of the reserves compared to the traditional first nations boundaries.

config.text:
Aamjiwnaang First Nations:

Chemical Valley

Chemical Valley


The region surrounding Sarnia, ON is typically referred to as "Chemical Valley". This region has the highest density of chemical manufacturing plants in Ontario as well as other production facilities like oil refineries, power plants, and oil and gas facilities. The Aamjuwnaang First Nations reserve is located in the middle of these facilities.

Contaminated Sites


Selecting the "Aamjiwnaang zoom" bookmark we see that this region is covered in facilities as well as both active and inactive contaminated sites. This does not mean that the facilities caused all these contaminations but it is worth noting.

Toronto Comparison


Now selecting the " Toronto" bookmark. Toronto shows much less contamination sites with less production facilities. This is significant because such a small population of people in Aamjiwnaang and the Sarnia region are subject to such a significant environmental hazard while the people of Toronto have relatively little concern for these environmental hazards.
Neskatanga has had the longest Boil Water Advisory of any reserve - 25 years. A water treatment facility was built in 1993, but it was inadequate.

Nearly all of the members of Neskatanga were evacuated to Thunder Bay in October, 2020, after elevated levels of hydrocarbons were detected in the water supply. The community returned to their homes after two months of living in hotels, but the BWA remained in effect.
Six Nations: Urban Water Crisis

Six Nations does not have a boil water advisory, despite the fact that only 9% of its residents had access to clean running water as of 2018. Six Nations has a state of the art water treatment plant, but 91% of the homes on reserves are not connected to it.

Six Nations is in an urban environment, meaning that it is a short drive away from world-class universities participating in this app challenge, like the University of Waterloo and McMaster University. The surrounding towns and businesses have clean, running water.

Six Nations is surrounded by mines, abandoned mines, other industry and pipelines. The surrounding communities enjoy relatively comfortable household income levels (toggle the layer on to see). And yet, Six Nations continues to face the environmental racism of unequal access to water.

The Chief of Neskatanga First Nation, Chris Moonias, said that until the Federal and Provincial governments ensure long-term, sustainable support for the water treatment facility, the BWA was necessary to prevent another evacuation.

Here we see the Neskatanga First Nations reserve with environmental contamination sites. Based on population size and area, a person living in Neskatanga First Nation has a 37.45% chance of living within 100km of any kind of contaminated site. A person living in Toronto, on the other hand, has a 0.12% chance of the same.


Select the available bookmarks to view the discrepancies.
Homeowners on reserves are responsible for the cost of all connecting infrastructure including plumbing, which can cost up to $70,000 in total per home.

The Federal Government promised to end drinking water advisories on reserves by March 2021, and did not.

Find your MP at this link and tell them that we are sick of excuses!
